text.tspan: Welcome to Inkscape! This tutorial will
demonstrate the basics of using the program.
This is a regular Inkscape document that you can
view, edit, or even save.
Panning the canvas
There are many ways to pan (scroll) the document canvas. Try
Ctrl+arrow keys to scroll by keyboard. (Try this now to scroll this
document down.) You can also drag the canvas by the middle mouse
button. Or you can use the scrollbars (press Ctrl+B to show or hide
them). Scroll wheel on your mouse also works for scrolling vertically;
press Shift with the wheel to scroll horizontally.
Inkscape tools
The toolbar on the left provides the main drawing and editing tools.
The top panel (below the menu) displays buttons and controls that
are specific to each tool. The status bar at the bottom of the window
will display useful hints and messages as you work.
Many operations are available through keyboard shortcuts. Open
Help | Keyboard Shortcuts to see the complete reference.
Zooming in or out
The easiest way to zoom is by pressing - and + (or =) keys. You can
also click the middle mouse button (Shift+click zooms out), or rotate
the wheel with Ctrl. Or, you can click in the zoom entry field (in the
bottom left corner of the document window), type a precise zoom
value in %, and press Enter. Finally, we also have the Zoom tool (in
the toolbar on left) which lets you to zoom in by dragging around an
area.
Creating and managing documents
To create a new empty document, use File | New or press Ctrl+N. To
open an existing SVG document, use File | Open (Ctrl+O). To save,
press Ctrl+S, or Shift+Ctrl+S to save under a new name. (Inkscape is
still unstable, so remember to save often!)
Inkscape opens a separate document window for each document. You
can switch between them using your window manager (e.g. by
Alt+Tab), or you can use the Inkscape shortcut, Ctrl+Tab, which will
cycle through all open document windows. (Create a new document
now and switch between it and this document for practice.)
Creating shapes
Time for some nice shapes! Click on the Rectangle tool in the toolbar
(or press F4) and click-and-drag, either in a new empty document or
right here:
As you see, default rectangles come up blue, with a 1pt stroke, and
partly transparent. We'll see how to change that below. You can also
create ellipses, stars, and spirals:
Moving, scaling, rotating
The most frequently used Inkscape tool is the selector. Click the
topmost button with the arrow on the toolbar (or press F1 or Space).
Now you can click on any object on the canvas. Click on the
rectangle below.
You will see eight blue handles appear around the object. Now you
can:
To undo your last action, press Ctrl+Z. (Or if you change your mind
again, you can redo the undone action by Shift+Ctrl+Z.)
Move the object by dragging it. (Press Ctrl to restrict movement
to horizontal and vertical.)
Scale the object by dragging any handle. (Press Ctrl to preserve
the original height/width ratio.)
Now click the rectangle again. The handles change. Now you can:
Rotate the object by dragging corner handles. (Press Ctrl to
restrict rotation to 15 degree steps.)
Shear (skew) the object by dragging non-corner handles.
You can also use the keyboard to move (arrows), scale (< and >
keys), and rotate ([ and ] keys) objects. Or, you can use the top panel's
entry fields to set exact values for coordinates (X and Y) and size
(W and H) of the selected object.
Multiple selections
You can select any number of objects simultaneously by
Shift+clicking them. Or, you can drag around the objects you need to
select; this is called "rubberband selection". (Selector creates
rubberband when dragging from an empty space; however, if you
press Shift before starting to drag, Inkscape will always create the
rubberband.) Practice by selecting all three of the shapes below:
Now, use rubberband (by drag or Shift+drag) to select the two ellipses
but not the rectangle:
Fill and stroke
Many of Inkscape's functions are available via dialogs. The commands
to open dialogs are all in the Dialogs menu. We'll now use the Fill
and Stroke dialog (Shift+Ctrl+F) to edit colors of objects. Select the
shape below and open the Fill and Stroke dialog.
You will see that the dialog has three tabs: Fill, Stroke paint, and
Stroke style. The Fill tab lets you edit the fill (interior) of the selected
shape(s). Using the buttons just below the tab, you can select no fill
(the button with the X), flat fill, linear or radial gradients. For the
above shape, the flat fill button will be activated.
Further below, you see the color picker — or, more precisely, a
collection of several pickers, each in its own tab: RGB, HSV, CMYK,
and Wheel. Perhaps the most convenient is the Wheel picker, where
you can rotate the triangle to choose a hue on the wheel, and then
select a shade of that hue within the triangle. All color pickers contain
a slider to set the alpha (transparency) of the object(s).
Whenever you select an object, the color picker is updated with its
current color. Play with these samples or create your own:
Using the Stroke paint tab, you can remove the stroke (outline) of the
object, or assign any color or transparency to it:
The last tab, Stroke style, lets you set the width and other parameters
of the stroke:
Finally, you can create gradients, instead of flat color, for both fills
and strokes:
Duplication, alignment, distribution
One of the most common operations is duplicating an object by Ctrl+D.
The duplicate is placed exactly above the original and is selected, so
you can drag it away by mouse or by arrow keys. For practice, try to
fill the line with copies of this black square:
Chances are, your copies of the square are not properly aligned. This
is where the Align dialog is useful. Select all the squares (Shift+click
or drag a rubberband), open the dialog (from the Dialogs menu or by
Shift+Ctrl+A) and press this button on the Distribute tab:
The objects are now distributed so that the horizontal intervals
between them are equal. Other alignment and distribution examples:
Z-order
The term z-order refers to the stacking order of objects in a drawing,
i.e. to which objects are on top and obscure others. The two commands
in the Object menu, Bring to Front (Home) and Send to Back (End),
will move your selected objects to the very top or very bottom of the
document's z-order. Two more commands, Raise (PgUp) and Lower
(PgDn), will move the selection by one step, i.e. past one non-selected
object in z-order (regardless of whether it overlaps the selection or
not).
Practice in using these commands by reversing the z-order of the
objects below, so that the leftmost ellipse is on top and the rightmost
one is at the bottom:
A very useful selection shortcut is the Tab key. If nothing is selected,
it selects the bottom object in the document's z-order; otherwise it
selects the next object above the selected object(s) in z-order. Shift-Tab
works in reverse, starting from the topmost object and proceeding to
the bottom. Since the objects you create are added to the top of the
stack, pressing Shift-Tab with nothing selected will conveniently
select the object you created last. Practice the Tab and Shift+Tab keys
on the stack of ellipses above.
Editing rectangles
The node tool (second from top in the toolbar on the left) is a
powerful tool for changing the shape of objects. For each of the shape
types supported by Inkscape, it does some useful shape modification.
For example, with rectangles, you can use it to round corners. Select
a rectangle, switch to the node tool (F2) and drag one or both of the
controls in the top left corner of the rectangle:
If you dragged one of the controls, the rounded corner will be circular
(and this circularity is preserved even after the rectangle is scaled
non-uniformly). Dragging both handles will let you create elliptic
corners with different proportions.
Editing ellipses
For ellipses, the node tool lets you create various segments and arks:
If you stay within the ellipse when dragging the control, you're creating
an arc; otherwise, a segment. Pressing Ctrl will limit your radius angle
to 15 degree increments. Note that the arcs (two rightmost shapes
above) are unclosed shapes, i.e. the stroke only goes along the ellipse
but does not connect the ends of the arc.
Editing spirals and especially stars with the node tool is pure fun:
Editing spirals and stars
Setting the number of rays of a star, the number of revolutions and
other parameters of a spiral is done via the Tool Options dialog.
The easiest way to create an arbitrary shape is to draw it using the
freehand (pencil) tool (F6):
Drawing freehand lines and Bezier curves
If you want more regular shapes, use the bezier (pen) tool (Shift+F6):
With this tool, each click creates a sharp node; click and drag
creates a Bezier node with two opposite handles. Press Shift to create
a Bezier node with only one handle. As usual, Ctrl limits the direction
the line segment or Bezier handles to 15 degree increments. Pressing
Enter finalizes the line, Esc cancels it.
In both freehand and bezier tools, pressing "a" will display anchors at
the ends of the currently selected path, allowing you to continue this
line instead of creating a new one.
Editing paths
Unlike shapes created by shape tools, the freehand and bezier tools
create what is called "paths". A path is a sequence of line segments
and/or Bezier curves which, as any other Inkscape object, may have
arbitrary fill and stroke properties. But unlike a shape, a path can be
edited by freely dragging any of its nodes (and not just predefined
controls). Select this path with selector and then switch to node tool:
You will see a number of gray square nodes on the path. Just like
objects with selector, these nodes can be selected by clicking,
Shift+clicking, or by dragging a rubberband. Selected nodes become
highlighted and show their control handles — the small circles
connected to to their nodes.
Paths are edited by dragging their nodes and nodes' handles. Ctrl works
as usual by restricting movement and rotation. The arrows, Tab, [, ],
<, > keys work as they do in selector, but apply to selected nodes. You
can delete (Del) or duplicate (Shift+D) selected nodes. The path can
be broken (Shift+B) at the selected nodes, or if you select two
endnodes on one path, you can join them (Shift+J).
Nodes can be made cusp (Shift+C), which means their handles can
move independently; smooth (Shift+S), which means their handles are
always on the same straight line; and symmetric (Shift+Y), which is
the same as smooth, but the handles also have the same length.
Converting to paths
Any shape or text object can be converted to path, which does not
change its appearance but removes all capabilities specific to this
shape, allowing you to edit its nodes instead. Here are two stars, one
is kept a shape and the other converted to path. Switch to node tool
and compare their editability (when selected):
Moreover, any path's stroke can be "outlined", i.e. converted to a
path. Below, the first object is the original path (no fill, black stroke),
while the second one is converted to path (black fill, no stroke):
Boolean operations
The commands in the Path menu let you combine two or more objects
using boolean operations:
Original shapes
Union (Ctrl++)
Difference (Ctrl+-)
(bottom minus top)
Intersection
(Ctrl+*)
Exclusion
(Ctrl+^)
Conclusion
This tutorial shows only a part of all capabilities of Inkscape. We hope
you enjoyed it. Don't be afraid to experiment and share what you
create. Please visit www.inkscape.org for more information, latest
versions, and help from user and developer communities.
Grouping
Several objects can be combined into a group. A group behaves as a
single object when you drag or transform it. Below, the three objects
on the left are independent; the same three objects on the right are
grouped. Try to drag the group.
To group, you select one or more objects and press Ctrl+G. To
ungroup one or more groups, select them and press Shift+Ctrl+G.
Groups themselves may be grouped, just like any other objects;
such recursive groups may go down to arbotrary depth. However,
Shift+Ctrl+G only ungroups the topmost level of grouping in a
selection; you'll need to press Shift+Ctrl+G repeatedly if you want
to completely ungroup a deep group-in-group.
You don't necessarily have to ungroup, however, if you want to edit
an object within a group. Just Ctrl+click that object and it will be
selected and editable alone, or Shift+Ctrl+click several objects
(inside or outside any groups) for multiple selection regardless of
grouping. Try to move or transform the individual shapes in the
group (above right) without ungrouping it, then deselect and select
the group normally to see that it still remains grouped.
XML editor
The ultimate power tool of Inkscape is the XML editor (Shift+Ctrl+X).
It displays the entire XML tree of the document, always reflecting
the current state. You can edit your drawing and watch the
corresponding changes in the XML tree. Moreover, you can edit any
text, element, or attribute nodes in the XML editor and see the result
on your canvas. This is the best tool imaginable for learning SVG
interactively, and it allows you to do tricks that would be impossible
with regular editing tools.
